newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila Central Bank raises reverse repo rates.
newsitem.headline: Manila Central Bank raises reverse repo rates.

text.p: The Philippine Central Bank said on Thursday it raised its borrowing rate by 0.25 percentage points on reverse repos of one to six months.
The one-month reverse repo rate now stands at 10.5625 percent from 10.3125 percent, the two months at 10.625 percent from 10.375 percent and six monthsat 10.875 percent from 10.625 percent.
It also lifted its rate on the 90-day special series T-bill rate to 10.7 percent from 10.3 percent.
But the Central Bank left its five-day reverse repo at 11.0 percent.
Earlier, the Central Bank said it lowered its overnight borrowing rate to 11.25 from 11.50 percent.
Traders said the Central Bank's action was intended to encourage banks to lock up money for longer periods.
"It's to make the yield curve a little positive," a trader said. "There's a lot of liquidity in the system. The Central Bank wants to keep rates at these levels."
But the lowering of the overnight borrowing rate meant that the speculation in the peso had tamed somewhat, traders said.
In the past seven days, the Central Bank lifted its overnight borrowing rate twice to bring the total increase to 1.25 percentage points to quell peso speculation brought on by stock market sales.
